In a remarkable achievement that underscores its ongoing commitment to public safety, Abu Dhabi has once again been named the world‚Äôs safest city in the latest Numbeo Global Safety Index, marking the tenth consecutive year the UAE capital has topped the global rankings. Ever since, the capital has retained this title, outpacing major global cities and reinforcing confidence in its public safety infrastructure.According to Numbeo, a crowdsourced database widely used in global cost of living and quality-of-life comparisons, Abu Dhabi excels in perceived safety from crime and comfort in public spaces.Its top ranking in ‚Äúsafety when walking alone at night‚Äù and ‚Äúsafety when walking alone during the day‚Äù reflects widespread public confidence, a core measure in the index that resonates with both locals and visitors.Experts say this consistency is not accidental. Multiple international rankings have linked safety with quality of life, economic opportunity and tourism appeal, all areas where Abu Dhabi continues to excel.For expatriates, the reassurance of safety has a tangible impact on life decisions. A significant portion of the foreign workforce now sees the UAE, especially Abu Dhabi, as not just a place to work but a place to settle permanently. Recent surveys show that nearly one in five expatriates express a desire to remain in the UAE long term, citing safety, security and stability as key factors.Local authorities have made safety a centerpiece of broader development strategies, connecting public reassurance with ambitious urban plans, community spaces and cultural initiatives that encourage inclusive, open-air living with minimal risk. From parks and waterfront promenades to family-friendly zones and business corridors, safety enhances every aspect of city life.Abu Dhabi is not alone in showcasing Gulf safety leadership. In the latest Numbeo data, Ras Al Khaimah, Ajman and Sharjah also ranked among the world‚Äôs safest cities, while Dubai placed notably high as well, illustrating the UAE‚Äôs regional strength in secure living environments.Further afield, broader UAE safety rankings have placed the country itself among the top safest nations in the world, reflecting not just urban safety but national policies that prioritise low crime, public trust, and cohesive civic engagement. According to the broader Numbeo Safety Index, the UAE recently secured the title of the safest country globally, ahead of other high-ranking nations, thanks to consistent low crime rates, high perceptions of personal safety, and low discrimination indices.One of the most striking aspects of Abu Dhabi‚Äôs ranking is its dual strength in daytime and nighttime safety, a benchmark that reflects well-lit, secure urban design, effective patrolling and community trust in public spaces. Travel guides consistently highlight Abu Dhabi as a welcoming destination where visitors can explore cultural venues, beachfronts, markets and public attractions with minimal safety concerns. This is an important draw in a travel environment where safety is a growing priority for global tourists.Abu Dhabi‚Äôs decade-long reign as the world‚Äôs safest city is more than a headline; it is a symbol of what sustained, strategic action can achieve in urban governance. In a world where many cities face rising crime, social tensions and public anxiety, Abu Dhabi‚Äôs approach has delivered consistent results that resonate beyond borders.Security experts note that such an achievement requires holistic policies, not just law enforcement but social cohesion, technology integration and inclusive development. Abu Dhabi‚Äôs safety model now serves as a case study for other cities looking to improve urban security without compromising personal freedoms or quality of life.In a period of global uncertainty, from economic pressures to geopolitical tensions, Abu Dhabi‚Äôs leadership in safety provides a rare constant and a place where residents can walk freely anytime, families can thrive and visitors can explore without fear. Local reaction reflects pride and reassurance. Many residents credit the city‚Äôs low crime environment for enhanced everyday life, from children playing outdoors to women feeling secure walking alone at night.Safety is not just a statistic, it is a lived reality that shapes how people move, work and socialise in the capital. Policing authorities emphasise that the ranking is not a one-time win but part of a long-term commitment. Officials reaffirm that continuous investment in smart systems, training and community programmes ensures that safety is not just achieved, it is sustained.As Abu Dhabi celebrates its tenth consecutive year as the world‚Äôs safest city, the achievement stands as a global benchmark for urban governance. It highlights how technology, proactive planning, community engagement and proactive law enforcement can create environments where people feel secure and free.For families, investors, expatriates and travellers, Abu Dhabi‚Äôs enduring top ranking is not just recognition. It is a reassuring promise of safety that continues to define the city‚Äôs identity in 2026 and sets a standard for cities around the world.

Article Title: Aadhaar enters US SSN debate: Far-right political writer Curtis Yarvin sparks backlash with anti-India slur
Article Text:

Far-right political writer Curtis Yarvin has triggered backlash online after pulling India‚Äôs Aadhaar biometric identity system into a debate about the weaknesses of the US Social Security Number (SSN). The exchange quickly became a flashpoint in a growing conversation about how outdated identity systems leave economies exposed to fraud, even as modern biometric tools become more widely discussed.Yarvin was responding to a post that argued the US should move beyond SSNs as the default identity backbone. The message he quote-posted read:‚ÄúIt‚Äôs strange that SSN is not linked to physical person with a biometric. It should be like your own physical key that works only for you and for no one else.India built iris+fingerprint system for national ID. Good foundational service for many things.‚ÄùThe point of the post was to praise Aadhaar as a scalable identity layer, and to suggest the US could modernise its own system by adopting a stronger ‚Äúproof-of-person‚Äù model.Yarvin‚Äôs reply, however, became the headline for the wrong reason. Instead of sticking to a policy critique, he used racist meme-style wording aimed at Indians, which many saw as a cheap insult dressed up as commentary.Curtis Yarvin is a polarising American writer and software developer, best known for his earlier blogging under the pseudonym ‚ÄúMencius Moldbug‚Äù. He is widely associated with neo-reactionary politics and has built a following by attacking democratic institutions, what he calls entrenched bureaucratic power, and the wider liberal political order in the US. He has also been repeatedly criticised for flirting with racist and extremist-adjacent ideas, and for promoting a worldview that rejects egalitarianism.Yarvin does not believe modern democracy is a legitimate or functional system. Instead, he argues in favour of a more centralised, authoritarian-style model of governance, where power is concentrated under a single executive who can ‚Äúrun the state‚Äù more like a company and override what he views as bureaucratic paralysis. Supporters describe it as a foundational digital infrastructure system because it allows identity verification to work more reliably across services.In the context of the US debate, Aadhaar is often referenced as proof that a large country can implement a modern identity layer tied to a real person, rather than relying on a number that can be stolen or misused.SSNs were created as an administrative identifier, not as a secure authentication tool for the internet era. Over time, they evolved into a de facto identity key used across financial services, credit, and verification systems, despite not being designed for that role.That mismatch has long fuelled concerns about identity theft and fraud, particularly as personal data breaches and synthetic identity scams become more common. Critics argue the US needs a stronger identity framework that can prove a person is real and present, not just in possession of a leaked number.
Article Summary: Far-right political writer Curtis Yarvin has triggered backlash online after pulling India‚Äôs biometric identity system into a debate about the weaknesses of the US Social Security Number (SSN) Yarvin quote-posted a thread praising the fingerprint-and-iris-based verification model as a stronger way to link identity to a real person. Article Title: Massive blaze at Karachi mall: Death toll rises to 14; rescue operations continue
Article Text:
Karachi mall fire (AP image)

The death toll from a major fire at an old shopping mall in Pakistan‚Äôs Karachi has risen to 14 after rescue teams recovered eight more bodies from the debris, officials said on Monday.The blaze broke out late Saturday night at Gul Plaza, a multi-storey wholesale and retail market on MA Jinnah Road in the city‚Äôs Saddar area. The fire was brought under control by Sunday night, but rescue operations continued as large parts of the building suffered severe structural damage.Six bodies were found soon after the fire erupted, with officials saying the victims likely died of suffocation. Dozens of injured people were rushed to nearby hospitals. As the fire spread rapidly, thick smoke and intense heat initially prevented rescue teams from entering the building.‚ÄúOnce the fire was doused, we didn‚Äôt wait for the cooling period and forcibly went in to rescue trapped people and we found eight more bodies, some badly charred,‚Äù Rescue 1122 Chief Operating Officer Abid Jalal told PTI.Jalal said the fire had almost completely damaged the building, with both the front and rear portions collapsing due to weakened pillars.‚ÄúThe structure has become extremely unsafe, and we are still searching as there is a risk of further collapses,‚Äù he said.Gul Plaza, built in the early 1980s, houses around 1,200 shops spread across a basement, mezzanine and three upper floors. It has long been a prominent commercial hub in Karachi.Sindh Governor Kamran Tessori, who visited the site on Monday, said authorities feared that dozens of people could still be trapped inside. ‚ÄúWe are extremely concerned and alarmed. Efforts are going on to find them but this is a national tragedy,‚Äù he told reporters.South Deputy Inspector General of Police Syed Asad Raza said the casualty count could rise as large sections of the building were yet to be searched. Officials suspect an electrical short circuit may have caused the fire, though the exact cause will be confirmed after a full investigation.The incident has once again highlighted serious fire safety concerns in Karachi. Article Summary: The death toll from a major fire at an old shopping mall in Pakistan's Karachi has risen to 14. Rescue teams recovered eight more bodies from the debris, officials said on Monday. Article Title: Middle East: Trump invited PM Shehbaz Sharif to join Gaza 'Board of Peace', says Pakistan

Article Title: Massive blaze at Karachi mall: Firefighter among six killed, many feared trapped

Rescue officials said cracks had appeared in the mall‚Äôs walls, while a DawnNewsTV correspondent reported that one side of the building had ‚Äúcompletely collapsed‚Äù. The News International said poor ventilation and sealed windows had allowed smoke to fill the interior, severely hindering rescue operations.Sindh Labour and Social Protection Minister Saeed Ghani warned that many people could still be inside the building. Sindh chief minister Murad Ali Shah has ordered an inquiry, directing Karachi Commissioner Hassan Naqvi to investigate the incident and submit a report.Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and President Asif Ali Zardari expressed grief over the loss of lives, as attention once again turned to poor fire safety standards in Karachi, where deadly mall fires have occurred repeatedly, including one in November 2023 that killed 10 people.

Article Title: Pakistan: At least 23 killed in separate road accidents amid dense fog; six children among dead

Article Title: Shaksgam Valley: India bristles over China's fresh claim
Article Text:
Why China Building Roads In Shaksgam Valley Is A Direct Strategic Challenge For India In Kashmir

What is the Shaksgam Valley?

What is the dispute about?

Why does Shaksgam Valley matter strategically?

Proximity to Siachen and Ladakh



The valley lies close to the Siachen Glacier, where Indian and Pakistani troops have been locked in a military standoff for decades. Chinese activity in the area adds a third actor to an already volatile theatre. China-Pakistan strategic depth



The region provides China and Pakistan with contiguous territorial access, enabling coordination between Xinjiang and Gilgit-Baltistan. This was impossible before the 1963 agreement. Military and logistics implications



Infrastructure in the Shaksgam Valley improves China‚Äôs ability to move troops, equipment and supplies near India‚Äôs northern frontiers, particularly Ladakh. Precedent for territorial claims



For India, accepting Chinese control over Shaksgam would weaken its legal position on PoK as a whole and dilute the 1994 parliamentary resolution asserting that the entire region belongs to India.

What has MEA said?

What China said?

What is the China-Pakistan boundary agreement of 1963?

Why does India call the 1963 agreement illegal?

Pakistan is an occupying power: New Delhi holds that Pakistan‚Äôs control over parts of Jammu and Kashmir is illegal, making any territorial transfer invalid.

Violation of India‚Äôs sovereignty: Any alteration of borders in Jammu and Kashmir without India‚Äôs consent infringes upon its territorial integrity.

Dangerous precedent: Accepting the agreement would legitimise third-party involvement in the Kashmir dispute. This legal position has remained unchanged across governments and decades.

What is CPEC and how does it link to Shaksgam Valley?

Why is China pushing infrastructure in this area now?

Securing Xinjiang‚Äôs western approache

Protecting CPEC assets amid militant threats in Pakistan

Signalling resolve after standoffs in eastern Ladakh

Reinforce claims through physical presence

Infrastructure, in this sense, becomes both a logistical asset and a political statement.

Where does Pakistan stand?

What happens next?





NEW DELHI: China‚Äôs fresh assertion that the Shaksgam Valley ‚Äúbelongs to China‚Äù has reopened a largely forgotten but strategically explosive fault line in the long-running Kashmir dispute. Beijing‚Äôs defence of infrastructure construction in the region -- tied closely to the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) -- has drawn a sharp response from New Delhi, which has once again described the area as an ‚Äúintegral and inalienable part of India‚Äù.The disagreement is not merely semantic. At stake are territorial sovereignty, India‚Äôs claims over Pakistan-occupied Kashmir (PoK), China‚Äôs growing footprint in the western Himalayas, and the future shape of regional connectivity linking Xinjiang, Gilgit-Baltistan and the Arabian Sea.This explainer breaks down what the Shaksgam Valley is, why it matters, the legal roots of the dispute, what India and China have said, and how CPEC and the 1963 China-Pakistan boundary agreement fit into the larger geopolitical picture.The Shaksgam Valley -- also known as the Trans-Karakoram Tract -- is a sparsely populated, high-altitude region located north of the Siachen Glacier . It borders China‚Äôs Xinjiang province to the north, Pakistan-occupied Gilgit-Baltistan to the south and west, and the Siachen area to the east.Geographically inhospitable, the region is marked by glaciers, mountain passes and extreme weather. Politically, however, it is one of the most sensitive pieces of territory in the Kashmir puzzle.India maintains that the Shaksgam Valley is part of the former princely state of Jammu and Kashmir and therefore legally belongs to India. Pakistan , which has occupied parts of Jammu and Kashmir since 1947, transferred control of the area to China in 1963 ‚Äî a move New Delhi has never recognised.China currently administers the territory as part of Xinjiang and treats it as sovereign Chinese land.At its core, the dispute revolves around who has the legal authority to decide the fate of the Shaksgam Valley.India‚Äôs position is straightforward: Pakistan had no legal right to cede any part of Jammu and Kashmir to a third country because it is an occupying power in PoK. Any agreement signed by Pakistan concerning that territory is therefore ‚Äúillegal and invalid‚Äù.China and Pakistan argue otherwise. They say the 1963 China-Pakistan boundary agreement was a sovereign decision between two independent states to demarcate their frontier and bring stability to a previously undefined border.Beijing has now gone a step further by asserting that infrastructure development in the region is ‚Äúfully justified‚Äù, signalling that it considers the issue closed ‚Äî at least from its perspective.Despite its harsh terrain, the Shaksgam Valley holds outsized strategic importance for four key reasons:India‚Äôs response has been unusually firm and consistent. Ministry of external affairs spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal has categorically rejected both China‚Äôs claims and Pakistan‚Äôs role in facilitating them.‚ÄúShaksgam Valley is an Indian territory. We have never recognised the so-called China-Pakistan boundary agreement of 1963,‚Äù Jaiswal said during a weekly briefing.He added that India also does not recognise the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, which passes through territory ‚Äúunder forcible and illegal occupation of Pakistan‚Äù.Jaiswal underlined that the entire Union Territories of Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh are an integral and inalienable part of India, and said New Delhi has consistently protested attempts to alter the ground reality in the Shaksgam Valley.Importantly, India has also reserved the right to take necessary measures to safeguard its interests, language that signals both diplomatic and strategic options remain open.China‚Äôs response has been equally direct.Beijing's foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning rejected India‚Äôs objections, stating: ‚ÄúThe territory you mentioned belongs to China. It‚Äôs fully justified for China to conduct infrastructure construction on its own territory.‚ÄùShe said China and Pakistan had signed a boundary agreement in the 1960s and demarcated their border as an exercise of sovereign rights.On India‚Äôs criticism of CPEC, Mao repeated Beijing‚Äôs long-standing line that the project is an economic cooperation initiative aimed at development and improving livelihoods.Crucially, she added that the boundary agreement and CPEC do not affect China‚Äôs position on the Kashmir issue, which Beijing says should be resolved peacefully in accordance with UN resolutions and bilateral agreements.Signed on March 2, 1963, the China-Pakistan boundary agreement formally transferred 5,180 square kilometres of territory in the Shaksgam Valley from Pakistan-occupied Kashmir to China.At the time, Pakistan described the move as a provisional arrangement, pending the final settlement of the Kashmir dispute. The agreement includes a clause stating that once Kashmir is resolved, the sovereign authority would renegotiate the boundary with China.India rejected the agreement outright, arguing that Pakistan had no locus standi to sign away territory that legally belonged to India.For China and Pakistan, however, the agreement served a vital purpose: it created a shared land border, laying the foundation for their enduring strategic partnership.India‚Äôs objections rest on three pillars:The China-Pakistan Economic Corridor is a Beijing's flagship Belt and Road Initiative project valued at around $60 billion. It links China‚Äôs Xinjiang region to Pakistan‚Äôs Gwadar port through roads, railways, energy projects and industrial zones.Parts of CPEC pass through Gilgit-Baltistan, which is a part of PoK.While Shaksgam Valley is not the most visible segment of CPEC, its integration into Chinese logistics networks strengthens Beijing‚Äôs western connectivity and supports Pakistan‚Äôs role as China‚Äôs gateway to the Arabian Sea.India argues that CPEC directly infringes on its sovereignty, and has repeatedly warned against third-country participation in projects passing through PoK.Several factors appear to be driving Beijing‚Äôs assertiveness:Pakistan has backed China‚Äôs position, insisting that the 1963 agreement is valid and that CPEC is critical to its economic future.Islamabad recently announced the creation of a Special Protection Unit to safeguard Chinese nationals working on CPEC projects, underscoring how central the corridor has become to Pakistan-China ties.India, however, continues to describe Pakistan‚Äôs actions as illegal and accuses Islamabad of trading away territory that does not belong to it.In the short term, the dispute is likely to play out diplomatically, with India continuing to lodge protests and China proceeding with its projects.In the longer term, the Shaksgam Valley could emerge as another pressure point in the already strained India-China relationship, especially if infrastructure development alters the strategic balance near Ladakh and Siachen.For New Delhi, the challenge lies in defending its territorial claims without triggering escalation, while preventing the gradual normalisation of a situation it considers unlawful.The Shaksgam Valley may be remote and uninhabited, but it sits at the crossroads of India-China rivalry, Pakistan‚Äôs territorial gambits, and China‚Äôs westward expansion.China‚Äôs renewed claim and India‚Äôs firm rejection show that the issue is far from settled. What was once a quiet footnote to the Kashmir dispute is now re-emerging as a live geopolitical fault line ‚Äî one that could shape the strategic landscape of the Himalayas for years to come.
Article Summary: The Shaksgam Valley is a sparsely populated, high-altitude region. It borders China‚Äôs Xinjiang province to the north, Pakistan-occupied Gilgit-Baltistan to the south and west, and the Siachen area to the east. It is one of the most sensitive pieces of territory in the Kashmir puzzle. At stake are territorial sovereignty, India's claims over Pakistan- occupied Kashmir, and China's growing footprint in the Himalayas.

Article Title: Pakistan faces renewed scrutiny as nine more Baloch citizens reportedly disappear
Article Text:

A fresh surge of enforced disappearances has been reported across Balochistan, Karachi, and adjoining regions, with nine more Baloch citizens allegedly taken away by Pakistsecurity agencies in recent weeks.Human rights defenders stated that these incidents follow a familiar pattern: individuals are arrested without warrants, held in secret locations, and never brought before a court, as reported by The Balochistan Post.According to The Balochistan Post, sources in Mand, Kech district, stated that Abdullah, son of Iqbal, was whisked away and shifted to an unknown facility. According to another report, 17-year-old student Jamal Murad was apprehended in Gwadar on 2 January by CTD and Military Intelligence operatives, after which he disappeared.The Voice for Baloch Missing Persons (VBMP) continued its protest camp outside the Quetta Press Club, marking its 6,052nd day. He said detainees are denied legal rights, courts are bypassed, and new laws merely protect extrajudicial actions.He called on national and international bodies to take meaningful steps to end the crisis and secure the release of all missing persons, as reported by The Balochistan Post.

Pakistan on Saturday claimed that Iraq has expressed ‚Äúkeen interest‚Äù in acquiring JF-17 Thunder fighter jets and Super Mushshak training aircraft, following talks between the air chiefs of the two countries.According to a statement issued by the Pakistan Army, air chief marshal Zaheer Ahmed Baber Sidhu, chief of air staff of the Pakistan Air Force (PAF), met lieutenant general staff pilot Mohanad Ghalib Mohammed Radi Al-Asadi, commander of the Iraqi Air Force, during an official visit to Iraq.The discussions focused on enhancing bilateral military cooperation, including joint training, capacity building and operational coordination.‚ÄúThe Iraqi air chief praised PAF‚Äôs professionalism and technological advancement, expressed interest in benefiting from PAF‚Äôs world-class training and expressed keen interest in JF-17 Thunder fighter jets and Super Mushshak trainer aircraft,‚Äù the statement said, as quoted by news agency PTI.Both sides also agreed to pursue joint exercises and training initiatives to strengthen interoperability between the two air forces.The JF-17 Thunder is a single-engine, lightweight combat aircraft jointly developed by China‚Äôs Chengdu Aircraft Corporation and the Pakistan Aeronautical Complex.Pakistan has claimed that the aircraft proved its capabilities during last year‚Äôs conflict with India, although its effectiveness remains disputed.Pakistan had also deployed Chinese-origin J-10 fighter jets during the May 7‚Äì10 hostilities with India.The development comes days after Pakistan and Bangladesh air chiefs held talks on the ‚Äúpotential procurement‚Äù of JF-17 jets by Dhaka. However, Bangladesh has not officially confirmed any such plan.Pakistan‚Äôs defence minister Khawaja Asif recently claimed that the country has seen increased interest in its fighter aircraft following the May 2025 standoff with India. Article Title: 'Cry of a wounded conscience': Hindu man killed in Pakistan; sparks widespread protests in Sindh

Article Title: After Greenland, now Diego Garcia: Trump shifts focus to Indian Ocean; impact on India
Article Text:
Chagos Archipelago

Trump Targets Indian Ocean; Wants Diego Garcia Base for US Troops, Slams UK-Mauritius Chagos Islands

Diego Garcia base

The UK‚ÄìMauritius dispute and the deal

Diego Garcia: A contested legacy

How Diego Garcia is crucial for US

India's position: Would New Delhi welcome US control of Chagos?

How far is Diego Garcia from India

(With agency inputs)





After capturing Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro and repeatedly threatening to take control of Greenland, US President Donald Trump has now set his sights on a new target: the Chagos Archipelago in the Indian Ocean.Trump has criticised ally, the UK, over a deal that would give Mauritius ‚Äúownership‚Äù of the archipelago, which comprises over 60 islands. His concern centres on the chain‚Äôs largest island, Diego Garcia, which hosts the well-known joint British-American military base, also known as Diego Garcia.The Republican‚Äôs outburst came despite his own administration welcoming the agreement, describing it as a ‚Äúhistoric and monumental achievement.‚ÄùThe United Kingdom has ‚Äúowned‚Äù and administered the Chagos Islands as the British Indian Ocean Territory since 1965, three years before Mauritius gained independence from the UK. Mauritius‚Äô Constitution, however, includes the islands as part of its territory. During the 1960s and 1970s, up to 2,000 people were forced off the islands to allow the United States to build what became the Diego Garcia military base.The UK‚Äôs control of the archipelago and the forced removal of its local population led to international criticism and calls for sovereignty to be transferred to Mauritius.In 2022, negotiations began between the UK's then Conservative-led government and Mauritius and continued following the 2024 election of Keir Starmer and his Labour Party. Talks dragged on as Mauritius also witnessed a change in government and there were disputes over money, but the agreement was signed off in May 2025 after Britain had sought and received backing from the Trump administration.Under the treaty, which is currently in the ratification stage in the British parliament, the UK would pay Mauritius an undisclosed sum ‚Äî reportedly about $100 million a year ‚Äî for 99 years to control the islands.Washington has described the base, which hosts around 2,500 mostly American personnel, as ‚Äúan all but indispensable platform‚Äù for security operations in the Middle East, South Asia, and East Africa. It has supported America's military operations from Vietnam to Iraq and Afghanistan. In 2008, the US acknowledged that the base had also been used for secret flights transporting terror suspects.More recently, the United States deployed several nuclear-capable B-2 Spirit bombers to Diego Garcia amid an intense airstrike campaign targeting Yemen‚Äôs Houthi rebels.In addition to its strategic security interests in the Indian Ocean, particularly regarding China, New Delhi has quietly encouraged London to return sovereignty of the archipelago to Mauritius. For India, there is also a historical context. The US decision to establish a full-scale military base on Diego Garcia was made during the Richard Nixon administration, which had sided with Pakistan in the 1971 India-Pakistan war and even sent a naval task force into the Bay of Bengal to try to pressure India. Instead of backing down, India, backed by the-then Soviet Union (mostly present-day Russia), went on to liberate Bangladesh ‚Äî then East Pakistan ‚Äî ahead of the arrival of the US Navy's USS Enterprise, the world‚Äôs largest and most powerful aircraft carrier at the time.In September last year, India announced a $680 million (over Rs 6,000 crore) economic package for Mauritius. The assistance, provided through grants and lines of credit, also supports development and the monitoring of the Chagos Archipelago‚Äôs marine protected area.The 99-year lease agreement between the UK and Mauritius ensures continued US access to the Diego Garcia base. However, if Trump were to take over the Chagos Archipelago, Mauritius would lose ownership of the islands, and all agreements, including India‚Äôs $680 million economic package, would be rendered automatically null and void. This could also undermine India‚Äôs strategic interests in the Indian Ocean.
Article Summary: Trump has criticised ally, the UK, over a deal that would give Mauritius ‚Äúownership‚Äù of the Chagos Archipelago. His concern centres on the chain‚Äôs largest island, Diego Garcia, which hosts the well-known joint British-American military base.

Article Title: ‚ÄòCriminal in nature‚Äô: Yunus defends minority-related incidents in Bangladesh, says only 71 of 645 communal
Article Text:
"No Control Over Minority Violence In Bangladesh...": Former Indian Envoy Slams Yunus Govt

With inputs from agency)





Bangladesh‚Äôs interim government on Monday said that the majority of incidents involving members of minority communities in the country during 2025 were ‚Äúcriminal in nature‚Äù and not driven by communal motives, asserting that only 71 of the 645 cases recorded had communal elements.The statement, issued by the office of chief adviser Muhammad Yunus and later highlighted by him in a post on X, came days after India pressed Dhaka to ‚Äúswiftly and firmly‚Äù deal with attacks on minorities and described as ‚Äútroubling‚Äù attempts to attribute such incidents to extraneous reasons.Citing a year-long review of official police records from January to December 2025, the interim government said 645 incidents involving minority communities were documented nationwide based on verified FIRs, general diaries, charge sheets and investigation updates.‚ÄúWhile every incident is a matter of concern, the data presents a clear and evidence-based picture: the overwhelming majority of cases were criminal in nature rather than communal,‚Äù the statement said.According to the data, 71 incidents were identified as having communal elements. These included 38 cases of temple vandalism, eight incidents of arson, one case each of theft and murder, and 23 other incidents such as threats to break idols, provocative social media posts and damage to worship pavilions.Police cases were registered in 50 of these incidents, with arrests made in an equal number, while preventive or investigative measures were taken in the remaining cases.The remaining 574 incidents, the government said, were linked to criminal or social disputes unrelated to religion. These included neighbourhood disputes (51), land-related conflicts (23), theft (106), prior personal enmity (26), rape (58) and 172 cases of unnatural death. Police registered 390 cases in this category, filed 154 unnatural death reports and made 498 arrests, with additional measures taken in 30 incidents.The statement stressed that accurate classification was necessary to counter misinformation and enable effective law enforcement.‚ÄúWhile all crimes are serious and demand accountability, the data demonstrates that most incidents involving minority victims were not driven by communal hostility, but by broader criminal and social factors that affect citizens across religious and ethnic lines,‚Äù it said.However, the Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council (BHBCUC) questioned the government‚Äôs assessment.‚ÄúIf the government thinks these are not communal incidents, the question then is whether anyone can take the law into their own hands,‚Äù BHBCUC leader Kajal Debnath said, warning that such statements could embolden criminals and create a sense of impunity.India has repeatedly raised concerns over attacks on minorities in Bangladesh, particularly Hindus. On January 9, external affairs ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said, ‚ÄúWe continue to witness a disturbing pattern of recurring attacks on minorities as well as their homes and businesses by extremists,‚Äù adding that such incidents must be dealt with ‚Äúswiftly and firmly‚Äù.Relations between India and Bangladesh have remained strained since the interim government headed by Yunus took charge following the collapse of the Sheikh Hasina government in August 2024, with New Delhi continuing to flag concerns over minority safety.
Article Summary: Bangladesh's interim government says majority of incidents involving members of minority communities in the country during 2025 were ‚Äúcriminal in nature‚Äô The government says only 71 of the 645 cases recorded had communal elements. India has repeatedly raised concerns over attacks on minorities in Bangladesh, particularly Hindus.

Article Title: Hindu businessman beaten to death in Bangladesh
